bestBHT.bht: We must obey God rather than men, declares Peter, showcasing the apostles' unwavering commitment to preaching the Gospel. This emphasizes the moral necessity of obeying God's authority over human authority. The early leaders of Christianity demonstrate their fidelity to this principle, submitting to penalties imposed by the law while refusing to disobey God. They prioritize God's authority above all else, obedient to civil and ecclesiastical leaders only when their commands align with God's will. This challenges believers to prioritize God's authority and submit to Him above all earthly authorities.

Henry Alford: O we ought to obey... to obey God—opposed to the words your doctrine of the High Priest; and to his designation of our Lord as this man.
The whole is a perfect model of concise and ready eloquence, and of unanswerable logical coherence.
The great duty of preaching the Gospel of Christ is kept on its highest grounds.
Albert Barnes: We ought to obey ... - See the notes on Acts 4:19.
Marvin Vincent: To obey [πειθαρχειν]. Not often used in the New Testament to express obedience.
This is the special term for the obedience which one owes to authority [αρχη].
John Calvin: God doth set men over us in such sort with power, that he keepeth still his own authority safe and sound.
If a magistrate do his duty as he ought, a man shall in vain say that he is contrary to God, seeing that he dissenteth in nothing; yea, rather the contrary rule is then in force.
If a king, or ruler, or magistrate, do become so lofty that he diminisheth the honor and authority of God, he is but a man.
Philip Schaff: we must obey God rather than men
Not in this, the earliest Church history we possess, do we find any of the leaders of Christianity unfaithful to this principle

while they refuse utterly to obey any command which they feel would be contrary to the voice of God, we find them quietly, without murmuring, submitting as now to any penalty the law of the land enforced against them
Archibald T. Robertson: We must (δε). Moral necessity left them no choice.
They stood precisely where Peter and John were when before the Sanhedrin before (Acts 4:20).
Obey (πειθαρχειν). Old verb from πειθομα and αρχη, to obey a ruler. Only by Luke and Paul in the N.T.
John Gill: We ought to obey God rather than men."
Men, civil magistrates, and ecclesiastical rulers, are to be obeyed in things which are not repugnant to the will of God; but in things that are, God is to be obeyed, and not men.

From whence it appears that the apostles were to be justified in disregarding the council, and neglecting its orders; and which is no ways contrary to that obedience and submission, that is to be yielded to those that are in authority, in things civil and lawful.
John Wesley: In the name of all the apostles, said."
He does not now give them the titles of honour, which he did before."
This is, as it were, a continuation of that discourse, but with an increase of severity.

bhtAttempts.bht: We must obey God rather than men, declares Peter in a concise and eloquent manner that exemplifies the unwavering commitment of the early Church to preach the Gospel. This passage emphasizes the moral necessity of obedience to God's authority and showcases the apostles' steadfastness in the face of opposition. They stood firm, just as Peter and John did before the Sanhedrin, submitting to any penalty imposed by the law while refusing to disobey God. The leaders of Christianity in this early Church history were unwavering in their adherence to this principle, obedient to civil and ecclesiastical rulers in matters that aligned with God's will but unwavering in their obedience to God when authorities clashed with His word. This passage challenges believers to prioritize the authority of God above all else.

We must obey God rather than men, declares Peter, showcasing the apostles' unwavering commitment to preaching the Gospel. This emphasizes the moral necessity of obeying God's authority over human authority. The early leaders of Christianity demonstrate their fidelity to this principle, submitting to penalties imposed by the law while refusing to disobey God. They prioritize God's authority above all else, obedient to civil and ecclesiastical leaders only when their commands align with God's will. This challenges believers to prioritize God's authority and submit to Him above all earthly authorities.

In Acts 5:29, Peter's concise and eloquent statement, We must obey God rather than men, reflects the apostles' unwavering commitment to preaching the Gospel. They prioritize God's authority over human authority, submitting to penalties imposed by the law while refusing to disobey God. This moral necessity of obeying God's authority is emphasized, urging believers to prioritize God's commands above all else. The early leaders of Christianity exemplify this principle, obedient to civil and ecclesiastical leaders only when their commands align with God's will.

We must obey God rather than men, declares Peter, showcasing the apostles' unwavering commitment to preaching the Gospel. This emphasizes the moral necessity of obeying God's authority over human authority. The early leaders of Christianity demonstrate their fidelity to this principle, submitting to penalties imposed by the law while refusing to disobey God. They prioritize God's authority above all else, obedient to civil and ecclesiastical leaders only when their commands align with God's will. This challenges believers to prioritize God's authority and submit to Him above all earthly powers.

In Acts 5:29, Peter's concise and eloquent statement, We must obey God rather than men, reflects the apostles' unwavering commitment to prioritizing God's authority. The early leaders of Christianity faithfully adhered to this principle, submitting to penalties imposed by the law while refusing to disobey God. They exemplified the moral necessity of obeying God's authority over human authority, emphasizing the importance of obedience to God's commands above all else. This challenges believers to steadfastly prioritize and submit to God's authority, even when faced with opposition from earthly powers.
